entry.title: Combined summary - What to do when contentious soft fork activations are attempted
entry.summary: In a recent email exchange on the Bitcoin-dev mailing list, Jorge Timón and John Tromp discussed the differences in opinions regarding different Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIPs). Timón accused Tromp of making personal attacks against Andreas Antonopoulos for his opinions on bip8. However, Tromp pointed out that Timón himself had made a personal attack by calling Jeremy ignorant about bip8. The conversation then turned to the spreading of misinformation, with both sides accusing the other of doing so.Alicexbt, a member of the bitcoin-dev community, suggested that natural skepticism from ignorance should not be interpreted as opposition to the proposal and should be given small weight. In a separate email thread, Michael Folkson discussed his thoughts on the recent attempt to activate a contentious soft fork. He believes that it is totally unacceptable for one individual to bring the entire Bitcoin network to the brink of a chain split and proposes a personal cost to dissuade them from trying it again.In another discussion on the same mailing list, Ryan Grant defended the OP_CTV covenant proposal after Jorge Timón questioned Andreas' criticism. Ryan argues that OP_CTV covenants cannot restrict any address that the sender does not control. The discussion revolves around the concept of covenants in Bitcoin and the contributions made by individuals towards it.The video "Q&A with aantonop" discusses various topics related to covenants, regulations, and El Salvador. The speaker mentions that for those who want to do smart contracts, working on covenants is important. The conversation leads to the path of redemption in the Bitcoin community and how helping Bitcoin can lead to it. Jeremy's efforts towards advancing the covenants discussion are sincere and judged based on concrete contributions. Even if certain opcodes are never activated, Bitcoin is more secure due to critical bug fixes that Jeremy has already seen merged. Andreas is encouraged to research technical merits before communicating and join the vision of powerful contract covenants for decentralized money that can affect people's freedom.In a separate conversation, there is a mention of Bip8, and how someone needs to be open-minded to understand its analysis. The discussion then moves to a general talk about covenants, including "visacoin" described on technical Bitcoin forums. It is suggested that instead of just criticizing what others have done, one should work on their own covenant proposals.The email conversation between Jorge Timón and John Tromp sparked a discussion on irony. Timón claimed that those against bip119 are simply ignorant about it, just as one could claim that those against bip8 do not really understand it. The conversation then turned to the spreading of misinformation, with both sides accusing the other of doing so.Overall, the various email exchanges on the Bitcoin-dev mailing list highlighted the differences in opinions regarding different Bitcoin Improvement Proposals and the need for education and consensus-building within the community. Additionally, there were discussions on the recent attempt to activate a contentious soft fork and the concept of covenants in Bitcoin. The emails emphasized the importance of addressing misinformation and the need for individuals to work on their own covenant proposals rather than just criticizing others.
